column55: Suppose that you are doing a 16S marker analysis of the gut microbial community from a non-model worm.  This worm has a unique digestive tract evolved for the breakdown of a specialized diet.  Discuss a sequencing strategy, a number of challenges you expect to face, and what kinds of additional resources are needed to help explore your data set.
column56: Suppose that you are using the Illumina platform to sequence total DNA from soil samples.  For this particular study, the soil samples come evenly distributed from two plot types on a single farm - one growing corn, the other dairy cow pasture. Discuss one or more approaches you would take to analyze the data, as well as your expected sensitivity and specificity to taxonomic and functional sequence identification. Include in your discussion the technical limitations of your analysis.

column55: I would dissect different parts of the digestive tract and separately prepare those sections for sequencing. Challenges: 1) Food ingested by the worm prior to sampling and sequencing may have had microorganisms that are not inherent to the digestive system. 2) Considering it is a non-model worm, there may be novel 16S reads that do not correlate to any known taxa in the current databases. 3) Same species can have different 16S gene sequences. 4) Sequencing errors. Softwares such as Qiime or Mothur are needed to analyze the data set, from quality checking the reads to figuring out who's there and performing downstream statistical analyses.
column56: I would use the MEGAHIT workflow to analyze the data. Multivariate analyses would be performed to potentially show how the two sites can be distinguished by their microbial makeup and functional potential. There are various technical limitations, starting from DNA extraction efficiency to sequencing errors, that would effect downstream analyses, creating biases, false positives, or being unable to detect rare taxa.
column61: To become a computational master. I want to understand the workflow, but more importantly, familiarize myself with the semantics of bioinformatics so I can intuitively understand what particular parameters are doing and how I can optimize parameters for a particular data set. I also want to be able to know what multivariate analysis is appropriate for a particular hypothesis I want to test.

column55: Some of the initial problems that could occur would be a low quantity of DNA or inhibitors to 16S PCR or sequencing. These inhibitors could be from the worm's digestive tract, and could prevent the generation of usable data for analysis. Kits that isolate the DNA could also contain inhibitors as well. DNA may also have to be concentrated or cleaned so the DNA could be sequenced. In addition, the amount of data generated could be greater than computer resources that are available, so a supercomputer may be necessary to process the data with programs such as mothur.

column55: The first problem with studying a non-model worm with a unique digestive tract is that the publicly available datasets for these microbiome will be more limited.  Without a deeper prior understanding of this organism's microbiome, it is harder to know the "baseline" or "normal" gut contents of what your'e seeing, and to know if you're seeing any deviations from normal.  Comparing against other similar worm species can be helpful as long as you keep in mind the native differences.  Additionally, you can encounter more "unknowns" in lesser explored microbiomes.
column56: If by "total DNA sequencing," you mean whole genome sequencing, this study could possibly involve the surveying of functional genes/functional groups in the different soil types to look for differences in ecological function.  With these types of studies, getting a suite of chemical metadata on the soil, such as metals, DOC, anions and cations, can pair nicely with the metagenomic data.  This would allow a stronger link between seeing functional groups and the related chemistry (such as the nitrogen cycle).  The sensitivity can be better established with replicates, since soil metagenomes can be highly variable, as well as at varying timepoints/weather conditions.  Specificity depends strong on what genes are profiled, since some genes are better at determining phylogeny than others.  Some of the technical limitations include PCR inhibitors from the soil (MAJOR problem), and high variability from soil sampling that would muddy the differences between sites.
column61: I am looking forward to this workshop for a few reasons.  Primarily, to get a better understanding on using bioinformatic tools in the amazon cloud space, and secondarily, to become more familiar with the techincal aspects of all the tools (Mothur and R, definitely!)And since I'm the only research that uses QIIME at my office and I'm self taught, it would be nice to see how other users work with the program.

column55: Sequence deep on a worm or two. Capturing anaerobes would be challenging. Identifying novel/new microbes would be another challenge. Additional resources would include an anaerobes database for identifying otus.
column56: To analyze total DNA, I may want do shotgun sequencing. The DNA acquired may not represent living organisms, you are getting a snapshot of what is and was. Great depth is unlikely because you are not targeting a subgroup such as bacteria. Reconstructing the genomes of everything would be challenging. Furthermore, you are not delineating how organisms interact (you may be sequencing a worms gut bacteria, but you won't be able to tell that it came from the worm, thus you can only say that it is present in the sample)

column55: Using the Illumina MiSeq sequencing technology, I would sample the gut microbial community from several groups of worms -- those that had fasted, those who had fed recently, and those who had some set time to digest their specialized diet.  I would first identify the core gut microflora of worms -- so those gut bacteria found in all worm samples.  I would then identify unique microbes specific to each group (fasted, recently fed, partially digested, fully digested) and attempt to identify gut bacteria that are key to the digestive processes.  It would be helpful to know more about the specialized diet and what is was composed of - cellulose based, chitin, or other material that may need specialized microbes for degradation.  One of the main challenges would be able to identify these key microbes among a large data set of million of sequences and also being confident that your 16S primers have adequate coverage for microbes of interest..
column56: Identify OTUs in each sample, perform alpha diversity metrics to compare diversity within sample, and beta diversity analyses to compare between the corn form and the cow pasture.

column55: I would section the gut based on the anatomy of the worm's digestive track and have unique bar-codes for each section. Sampling challenges include, but are not limited to, sample replication and sectioning the digestive track into unique sections. Additional challenges could possibly be with DNA isolation and amplicon inhibition.
column56: One can look and within land-use treatment variation or between land-use treatment variation. Within the corn field, sampling must take in account the differences of sampling near the rhizosphere and bulk soil. Plant type within the cow pasture will also influence the microbial composition.

column55: I would extract bacterial DNA from worm fecal samples or dissect out the gut, then use 16S paired end illumina sequencing of the V3-V5 or V4 region. I would clean and analyze the data with cut adapt, QIIME, USEARCH, and R.A major challenge in using a non-model organism is that many OTUs will not match in greengenes, making it difficult to compare this worm's microbial taxonomy to other non-model worms with more standard diets. Trying to ask functional questions would also be difficult because a non-model organism may have only 60% of its microbiota map to known genes using picrust. It would be useful to know if other animals share the worm's odd diet (e.g. is it myrmecophagous?) and how their microbiota match up.
column56: If this were 16S amplicon sequencing, I would use QIIME to output alpha (species richness, shannon's h, chao1, and faith's phylogenetic diveristy) and beta diversity measures (weighted and unweighted unifrac, bray-curtis), and then I would analyze the data in R. I would test within and between plot diversity. A major technical limitation is only having 1 plot per land use type, making pseudoreplication an issue.

column55: Shotgun sequencing would be used to resolve the members making up the microbial community present within the non-model worm. In short DNA would be extracted from the gut of the worm, fragmented, and then sequenced (using sanger or pyrosequencing) to construct full length genomes for each microbial specie. The biggest challenge I would expect to face would be constructing the full length genome as this step requires a reference genome for alignment (needs to be available). In addition coverage depth will be an issue. If a particular microbe makes up, say .05% of the microbiota, its individual contribution to the whole may not be seen. The additional resources needed to complete this analysis would include but are not limited to, computational and statistical platforms, microbial databases and a competent student.
column56: Analyses of alpha and beta diversity would be completed in this scenario. I would want to know how many species are present at each site, what the functional potential of the species are at each site after treatment (treatment being plotted in the two separate environments) and how the two sites compare after the treatment. Not having statistical or computational power would be a technical limitation as the data generated in such a study would be plenty.

column55: I would suggest a PCR amplification of the 16S fragment, barcode each sample, and pool them for sequencing on an Illumina MiSeq chip. Different samples would include different "stages" in the digestive tract across different timepoints after feeding, repeated across many individuals. Given the capacity of a MiSeq chip, a high number of samples could be analyzed, so worms could be collected from geographically diverse sources. Expected challenges include limitations of 16S for identification, poor signal from low-abundance species, and presence of novel species that have low sequence similarity to reference species. Analysis of this dataset would require a reference database for 16S sequence comparison and filtration of any non-target DNA, such as mitochondrial DNA from the worms.
column56: For a total DNA sequencing experiment, I would expect a higher resolution from longer reads, since these are more likely to assemble accurately. I would make an attempt to filter bacterial and eukaryotic sequences or perform a de novo assembly. I would then BLAST my results against an NCBI or similar database to identify potential markers or source organisms. I expect to have low taxonomic sensitivity due to bias towards high-abundance organisms. Moreover, eukaryotic organisms, such as fungi or plants, may constitute a higher proportion of the total DNA in the samples. I expect to find a detectable and meaningful change in the functional gene profile between the samples, given the very different nutrient inputs and biological activities of corn and grazing pasture soils.

column55: There are different challenges to obtain a valuable dataset, first the method of sampling and extraction, since we are interested only on the gut microbiota, an appropriate method should be selected to avoid cross contamination with other microflora from different parts of the worm.  Also the DNA extraction method is important since the amplicons obtained will depend on the quality of DNA and reduced/no presence of contaminants.  The next step will be the selection of the region of 16S to be amplified and length of this region.  This is important for the sequencing method used, including the length of the amplicons and quality of the sequences obtained, so an amplicon of around 300 bp should be fine for identifying the gut microbiome.  Also the selection of the region will influence our ability to determine the existing microflora since the region is going to determine the "taxonomic" resolution that we can use to assign the different OTUs and also the biases from the method.  Therefore, based on this I will select an amplicon size of ~300 bp to use MiSeq or HiSeq with 2X250 bp, to have a good overlap when assembling the amplicons.Once the raw data is back, quality filtering and assembly are required, and there are different options for these analyses.  Then, a good database is required to proceed with the analysis.  Different databases will provide different answers, since your analysis depends on the database being used.  Usually for bacteria the best sources are greengenes or SILVA, which are curated databases for these analyses.  In most cases, NCBI (genebank or similar) are not best resource since miss-annotation and unclassified sequences are the most abundant.Using a particular a database different pipelines can be used to analyze the data, and then generate an OTU table that can be used for statistical analyses in R.
column56: The sequences will be assembled and quality trimmed.  Then, cluster the sequences to reduce redundancy and make the dataset manageable.  The sequnces left will be subjected to chimera analysis to reduce the chance of rare OTUs that introduce noise to the analysis.  After that, sequences will be analyzed against a curated set of sequences to assign taxonomic ranks to the different OTUs identified.  The reliability of the taxonomic ranks depends on the target region, but most cases family level is accurately assigned to OTUs, and in some cases even genera can be done from an assigned.  Once the OTUS have identified or assigned, using the stats and rarefaction, samples are subsampled to the same level to proceed with the actual analysis.One last thing sirloin the sequence analysis is using the database to identify  "contaminant" sequences such as chloroplast or mitochondrial 16s like sequences, that can confound the analysis and other contaminants that could be present. This is also related with sensitivity since they are going to affect the recovery of more or certain species, also since we are not amplifying a target region the sensitivity is going to be lower, especially for this rare species.  Since we are doing total DNA, the database is key to construct those genes to recover the taxonomy present in the sample.   The same is true for the functional analysis, thus the lack of annotation of genes or the reduced knowledge of bacterial/eukaryotic genomes are going to affect the assignment of function to Vegas found in th free samples.   Nonetheless, this has improved recently with dedicated databases to improve the assignment of these functional genes.With respect to the functional analysis, it is also important to mention that not all the genes or fragments of DNA sequenced will an active cell or live cell, therefore we have to acknowledge this limitation inherent to the method.The initial approach is to start comparing the abundance and richness of species between corn and pasture plot, however we are limited by locations since this study is conducted in a single location. Then focus on the overall functional assignment to determine if there are specific categories that drive the differences, and the focus on those are different or that  I am interested in such as those related to nitrogen cycling.  Also, correlate the differences in functional categories with the taxonomy assignment to determine trends of functions with certain species.

column55: After DNA extraction, I would do paired-end Illumina MiSeq amplicon sequencing of the 16S gene with universal primers cited in the literature.  After sequencing I would work with the fastq files and run it for quality scoring, alignment, and assigning of OTUs in Mothur.  Afterwards, I would input the shared (OTU table), the taxonomy file, a tree file, and metadata into R.  I would then rarefying (or scale) the number of sequences to each other and work using the phyloseq, vegan and ggplot2 packages to run statistics and create pretty graphs.
column56: I would check the quality score of the sequences and make sure they are high enough quality to use.  Then I would try to create large contigs of the sequences, which I could match to a database.  After matching the seqs to a database, I would then bin them into "populations" by using ESOM.  I would look at the ESOM output of the 2 different samples and then start data exploration.  The major limitations of my data would be how well my data matches a database, what is a good cutoff, how do we define a "match," among many others.
